comments.commentBody: Man oh man, I really think Apple made a huge mistake phasing out the 5.25" floppy disc drive back in '84. Millions of pc's had them as original equipment at the time Apple gave up on the technology. And one may still purchase the drives and disks and connect them to today's latest computers. Well, some of today's computers, anyway.
If it's so easy why isn't your mother playing in the big leagues?

A no-hitter is not small and petty... it is a life's accomplishment for a major league pitcher.  I applaud the organization for taking that into consideration and following through.  It is clearly an error when someone foregoes a glove catch completely and drops the ball.  There was no gurantee Upton beats a decent throw, but it was certain once the ball was dropped that he would make it.  In other words if he beats the throw then he gets the hit, but we shouldnt be biased about who is on the baseline when considering a dropped barehand attempt, and neither should the scorer. Its hard to believe that it was scored a hit, and I imagine that if it was in the late innings of a no-hitter it would get much more media attention.

I agree.  It was an error, but don't reverse the ruling to make it a no-hitter.  If it was late in the game, maybe.  But with the pressure building through 8 more innings, how can we know Dickey would've pitched the same?  Call it a great performance by our best pitcher and leave it at that.

Didn't see the game live, but when the highlight appeared on ESPN, it was obvious -- error, as Wright mishandled the big hop. The ESPN guys called it as Wright failing to make the one-handed pickup of a slow hit grounder. Uh-uh -- not this play.

A no-hitter? I don't think so -- who knows how Dickey pitches if he has a no-no going late. But the 1st inning ball was an error -- no question.

Isn't this call just the latest proof that official scorers cannot be employees of the home team? What is an error if not this play?

Gardner is one of the lower-paid Yankees, which is ironic because he's one of the most talented. I think his absence has been palpable, and if the pitching hadn't turned completely around we're flirting with Boston for bottom scraps, partly due to the lack of his speed. Also, though I dislike this, many feel Gardner is valuable for a possible trade later, so you want him as healthy as possible. I want him on the team!
In the old days, exercising with inflamed muscle tissue would cause such tissue to tear, thus turning a minor injury into a potentially career ending debacle.
In the old days he would still be in the lineup. I understand teams want to protect their substantial investments in players, but what's the return on the invest when they don't play?

This is wonderful. Thank you.

I love the phrase, "mutatis mutandis"..Wow!

Superhearts to Rajaji. Love that naughty man.

Other readers: any recommendations for a good biography of Rajaji? I'd love to read one.

In those days tussles were kept within bounds and not brought out in the open, but today it is different. The first outcome of the present bickering over Presidency is that Sonia is not the Sutradhari (prime conductor of dramas).She does not call the shots anymore. And there are so many hats in the ring.

In the interests of the dignity of the highest office, the contending sponsors should call off rival claims and settle on someone like, say Mr.Gopal Gandhi--who is a dignified , non-controversial person, and, what is more well-qualified for the post., one who will hold office with dignity.

Incredible India! Your image is at stake.
Ven Sardi, California
Not necessarily.  Have you ever heard of parental alienation?

Just because a grown child breaks off a relationship with a parent(s) do not assume that it is always the parents' fault.  There can be selfish, misled, or troubled children just as often as there are selfish, misled,or troubled parents.  If the spouse is selfish, troubled, resents or is jealous of the parents she/he will often add fuel to the fire.  Estrangement is painful and often, although not always, a cruel and intentional act on the part of the family member who breaks off the relationship.

Some of their stuff is visible even if you are not friended.  It's real easy to check on someone who has not privitized their wall or their photographs.  Some people want to be "out there."  Makes my job easy when I attempt to locate people absconding from responsibilities.
I fail to see how it is Facebook's problem if resentful former relatives "check up" on you. Ask them to stop. Take them off your friend's lists!
I agree.  I don't and have never used any social media and don't regret it at all.  I wonder if FB is like an addiction?

You're both (A.B. and lakegirl) commenting on the New York Times articles, online, with strangers, but you don't understand why people might want to use the internet to communicate with friends and family?

Lisbeth, I think you miss the point of the comments section. It is a release valve for irritation. I have noticed that everyone wants to write a book, but almost no one wants to read anyone else's book. The comments are along the same  lines. Most people are more concerned with speaking their minds than with whether anyone is listening. I wonder if FB (which I do not use) is not the same.
It is not clear to me why people are having trouble resisting > to use Facebook.  Please explain.  Someone.

@ Ellen

A joke is a joke is a joke! Take it easy. Where is Saudi Arabia's Kiran-Mazumdar Shaw or Chandra Kochhar?

I can rattle off a long list of Indian women prominent in science, business, education and politics. (though not half as long as we would like). My Saudi friends can't pull that off!

I agree.  I love technology and work with it well, whether it's an Iphone, Apple TV, streaming music and the like but FB is just not for me.  I don't want to know what others are doing.  I have a great relationship with my family and we talk often, but I just don't need to see it daily on FB nor do I feel the need to update people on my life moment to moment.  FB is great for some, just not for me.
JoeB, please read Wist45's post above yours. Some grudges are necessary - for mental and spiritual health.

I am experiencing the opposite of this, I have caught up on relatives that I lost contact with because of geographic distances.  For those who don't get along with their relatives, I am sorry for you.  Life is too short to hold grudges.  If you don't want to be found on facebook, you can always use a nom de plume.

Both presidential candidates realize, I hope, that our deficit will only grow worse if we continue to place so much importance on importing oil. This decline will continue, regardless of how many jobs are created.

There will not be a net energy benefit from extracting tar sands. Think about all the power and energy required to pump the extracted oil all the way from Canada to Texas. Drilling off the coast of Alaska is an insult to the natural beauty and mysticism of the state and I must say Obama really caved in to "peer pressure" on that one, but he has also done more than any previous president to make us energy dependent.

Thanks to President Obama, The United States reclaimed the title as the leading investor in renewable energy in 2011, which China had held in 2010. The U.S Military is now the leading global investor in renewable energy and is replacing generators, which require soldiers to transport oil through perilous valleys and terrain, with solar panels. Obama initiated the Global Fuel Economy Initiative, requiring automakers to improve U.S fuel economy to 35.5mpg by 2016, serving as a model for other countries as well. Had Romney been president, Ford, GM, and other American automakers would be toast and inspiring inventions such as the Chevy Volt, 50 mile charge and 37mpg on gas, would have been just a hindsight.

You are in possession of the TRUTH?! The much more comprehensive and scientifically done Global Gender Gap Index ranks India considerably above Saudi Arabia - though the overall ranking of India is regrettably still very poor.
And preferably some woman who doesn't equal Del/Mum?Blore with India?
Take it easy. It's a personal essay, not breaking news. You don't *have* to read it.

Once again Obama misspoke. He meant to say that the last presidential election shaped the economy for years. It definitely has, and the economy has been bad the past 3 1/2 years. And for those who squawk about those "nasty Republicans" preventing their dear Obama from creating a Utopian society, I say "get over it." There are hundreds of Republicans in Congress and one Obama (thank goodness). The chances of enough of those nasty Republicans going away to make it easy for Obama - slim to none. The chance of one president going away to perhaps facilitate some sort of change after this 3 + years of economic disaster - very good.

People halfway around the world were rooting for Mr. Obama in 2008. Including me.

What did Mr. Obama accomplish?

No closing of Guantanamo Bay. Perhaps incumbent presidents become privy to intelligence documents detailing the crazy lengths that terrorists go or can go to try and harm America. And that changes the mind of the President.

But what about Wall St? He kid gloved the hedge fund industry, and the billionaires and the tend-headed monster that is the banking industry.

On healthcare, he has tried to carry the baton forward from the Great Society platform created in the '60s.

Not much in terms of campaign finance reform or the lobbying industry.

Perhaps courageous attempts to curb the spiraling costs of healthcare for retirees and also curb the military industrial complex by cutting the defense budget.

Renewable energy usage expansion as well as trying to mitigate the burden of student loans on youngsters.

All this in a legislative framework of utter gridlock in Congress and a Supreme Court that is Conservative-heavy.

Summary: some promises kept, some tasks started, other challenges not taken on for various reasons.

All in all a mixed record. Obama fails on the yardstick of the historic changes he had promised during the 2008 campaign.

But then we the people perhaps should not have been so taken in by the lofty campaign rhetoric. Christopher Hitchens saw through it. We should have as well.

So vote for Obama in 2012? Sure. Or do a lot worse. Like vote Romney.

Today both President Obama and Mr. Romney doubled down on their well known and well worn positions. More spending vs. more tax cuts and reduced regulation. Unfortunately, the first tactic did not work over the past two years and the latter failed miserably in real sustainable economic and job growth in the previous eight.

What we are faced with is a structural problem and no economic and jobs revitialization program is going to get us moving again unless it involves substantial and long term 1)entitlement reform, 2) tax reform and 3) shared sacrifice by all socio-economic and age groups. So far both the President and the contender are offering general platitues which will, most likely if translated into specific policies (more appropriately extend and compund already proven unsuccessful ones) will simply reflect a status quo from either right or left.

To me, and I will bet a lot of independent minded voters looking for some creative and truly transendent economic policy, it is Tweedle Dee and Tweedle Dumber. You pick which one applies to your party's candidate.

I doubt there is any substantive difference between the two candidates. Both appear likely to continue the major economy-wrecking Bush policies: for-profit domestic and foreign "wars", and Wall Street control of the economy.

I dont think anyone is arguing whether the next president will shape our future. The important questions are how they will shape our future. Will our economy be dependent on government paychecks? or Will America manufacture items on a world market that compete or represent what a leading nation represents?

America is $15 Trillion in the hole. That equates to billions of our tax dollars paid out annualy in interest payments to other countries; some who are not, truly, our friends.

Any more spending means an increase in our debt and an increase in our interest payments.

Less taxes inhibits our ability to operate our country at a responsible level and makes it harder to pay the interest on our debt.

So, Democrats, you are wrong and right. Republicans, you are wrong and right.

I just can't seem to find it in me to give either side any praise or respect.

Actually, I'm not pleased that Obama waited 3 years to end the Iraqi war and continues placating the generals with open-ended war in Afghanistan and elsewhere BUT!, I give him great credit for saving us from a Depression that was inevitable due to Republican policies, and maintained a steady pattern of growth following the deep recession. How can you all forget we are actually growing economically? There has been steady growth with a two percent reduction in unemployment. It isn't Obama's fault if largely Republican run businesses don't hire. I am not at all surprised that the Republican party shirks reponsibility for our recent economic collapse in 2008. Informed people know it, and the Republicans know they can fool their clueless followers. Ignorance is bliss, isn't it?
